content: The Act is titled the "Fair Disaster Tax Relief Act of 2008" and pertains to losses related to federally declared disasters. The "Fair Disaster Tax Relief Act of 2008" amends the Internal Revenue Code to provide a special rule for losses in federally declared disasters, allowing individuals with a net disaster loss to claim additional deductions. The "Fair Disaster Tax Relief Act of 2008" allows individuals to claim deductions for personal casualty losses exceeding 10 percent of adjusted gross income, known as net disaster loss, attributable to federally declared disasters. The term 'federally declared disaster' refers to a disaster determined by the President to require Federal assistance under the Stafford Disaster Relief Act. The term 'disaster area' is the designated area for such assistance. Amendments include expanding the sections to include additional paragraphs. The amendments involve changing references from "Presidentially declared disaster" to "federally declared disaster" in the tax code sections related to property damage caused by disasters. The tax code amendments relate to property damage in disaster areas caused by federally declared disasters. The terms "federally declared disaster" and "disaster area" are defined in the code. The tax code is amended to define "federally declared disaster" and related terms in the context of property damage in disaster areas. The tax code is amended to define "federally declared disaster" and related terms in the context of property damage in disaster areas. Subsection (a) of section 7508A is updated to replace "Presidentially declared disaster" with "federally declared disaster." Additionally, the standard deduction is increased to include a disaster loss deduction. The tax code is amended to increase the standard deduction to include a disaster loss deduction. The limitation on individual loss per casualty is also raised from $100 to $500. The tax code amendments increase the standard deduction to include a disaster loss deduction and raise the individual loss per casualty limit to $500. The effective dates for these changes are after December 31, 2007, and after December 31, 2008 for specific amendments. SEC. 198A. EXPENSING OF QUALIFIED DISASTER EXPENSES. Part VI of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to allow for the expensing of qualified disaster expenses. A taxpayer can elect to deduct qualified disaster expenses as an expense not chargeable to capital account. These expenses must be related to a trade or business, including hazardous substance abatement or debris removal from business-related property damaged by a federally declared disaster. The taxpayer can deduct expenses for business-related property damaged in a federally declared disaster, which must be related to a trade or business and not chargeable to capital account. Business-related property includes property used for business purposes or income production. A federally declared disaster is defined as per section 165(h)(3)(C)(i). The taxpayer can deduct expenses for business-related property damaged in a federally declared disaster under section 165(h)(3)(C)(i). The deduction allowed for such expenses is treated as a deduction for depreciation, and the property is treated as section 1245 property for depreciation purposes. Sections 198, 280B, and 468 do not apply to expenses under this section. The Secretary will prescribe necessary regulations for implementation. The table of sections for part VI of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code is amended by inserting a new item after section 198. Sec. 198A allows for the expensing of Qualified Disaster Expenses, effective for amounts paid or incurred after December 31, 2007. Additionally, Section 4 addresses net operating losses related to federally declared disasters. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 allows for net operating loss carrybacks for taxpayers with qualified disaster losses, which can be carried back to the five preceding taxable years. Rules relating to qualified disaster losses are outlined in Section 172 of the Code. The term 'qualified disaster loss' refers to the lesser of losses allowable under section 165 for the taxable year attributable to a federally declared disaster and occurring in a disaster area, and the deduction for qualified disaster expenses allowable under section 198A(a). The taxpayer can elect to have the carryback period determined without regard to certain provisions, in a manner similar to specified liability loss treatment. The taxpayer can elect to have the carryback period determined without regard to certain provisions, in a manner similar to specified liability loss treatment. The Secretary must receive this election by the due date for filing the taxpayer's return for the taxable year of the net operating loss. Once made, the election is irrevocable for that taxable year. Additionally, in the case of a taxpayer with a qualified disaster loss, the net operating loss deduction for alternative minimum taxable income is increased by the sum of carrybacks and carryovers of such loss. The amendments made by this section apply to losses arising in taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007. SEC. 5. WAIVER OF CERTAIN MORTGAGE REVENUE BOND REQUIREMENTS AFTER FEDERALLY DECLARED DISASTERS. Paragraph (11) of section 143(k) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to provide special rules for federally declared disasters regarding a taxpayer's principal residence. If the residence is rendered unsafe or demolished due to a disaster, certain tax provisions will not apply for a 2-year period. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has special rules for federally declared disasters affecting a taxpayer's principal residence. If the residence is damaged, owner-financing for repair or reconstruction is treated as a qualified rehabilitation loan with certain limitations. The amendment allows for repair or reconstruction costs up to $150,000 for federally declared disasters after December 31, 2007.
